I will go out on a limb and say, "Yes, you do have free will because you made certain choices and your life was redirected as a result."

 Hey, if free will is an illusion, it is at least a very persistant one.

That is the problem, the definition. From a religious, philosophical or ethical viewpoint the implication is that we are free to act as we choose (separate from a deity or supernatural force) and as a result are responsible and culpable for any actions.
 
 Looking at it from a psychological, cognitive or physiologic point of view their are the issues of how our behavior is influenced by sub-conscious forces, behavioral stimuli, cognitive processes, past experiences and biological or genetic states. Science doesn't really know what a "mind" is.
 
 For simplicity, I think that there are no "outside" forces, so that we do have free will, in all its complexity, and at any given moment we do have the power to act as we choose. (How's that for a definition?)
 
 As to how things turn out, based on that behavior, most of it's due to us, though the situation we are plopped in and luck have a big say as well.
 
 Getting back to the original post, are you thinking things worked out well or not?

 You are a free moral agent. Free Moral Agency consists of intelligent, sensibility, and free will, and these form the foundation of moral obligation. 
 
 The intellect includes reason and self-determination. 
 
 The sensibility includes selfconsciousness, all sensation, desire, emotion, passion, and all feeling. 
 
 Free will is the power of choice concerning moral law. It is mans faculty of choosing good or evil without compulsion or necessity.
 
 The basis of right choice, or moral obligation is to act for the good of all. Nothing can happen in life but what is the choice of someone so it is important that right choices are made that will effect the greatest private and public good.

 free will is a person's ability to autonomously make a conscious decision and act accordingly. if you can act, but cannot control your actions, you dont have free will. if you can make a decision, but cannot execute, you are not exercising your free will. hope that helps
 
 i believe you have free will. making decisions that end up in your perception as "good" or "bad" does not make a case for or against free will. it only proves that your surroundings have an emotional impact on you, which is normal. your situation does sound like something that would depress the average person, but being depressed doesnt mean at all that you were predestined to fail. the problem is that some people succeed, or at least they percieve their personal situations to be favorable to them. does that mean that they were predestined to succeed? or was it that they made good decisions which led them to the situation they are in? see, it doesnt make sense that some people have free will and some dont. there would be no way to determine which had which, and occam's razor would obliterate that idea pretty quickly. either everybody has free will and are in control of the decisions and actions they make, or everybody is on a predestined path hat is beyond their control. and from what you said, you might actually making a stronger case FOR having free will (and being in the situation you are in as a result of your decisions) than for predestination.
